connector.description: Netty HTTP server and client using the Netty 4.x.

camel.sink.path.protocol.name: camel.sink.path.protocol
camel.sink.path.protocol.description: The protocol to use which is either http, https or proxy - a consumer only option. One of: [http] [https]

camel.sink.path.host.name: camel.sink.path.host
camel.sink.path.host.description: The local hostname such as localhost, or 0.0.0.0 when being a consumer. The remote HTTP server hostname when using producer.

camel.sink.endpoint.bridgeEndpoint.name: camel.sink.endpoint.bridgeEndpoint
camel.sink.endpoint.bridgeEndpoint.description: If the option is true, the producer will ignore the Exchange.HTTP_URI header, and use the endpoint's URI for request. You may also set the throwExceptionOnFailure to be false to let the producer send all the fault response back. The consumer working in the bridge mode will skip the gzip compression and WWW URL form encoding (by adding the Exchange.SKIP_GZIP_ENCODING and Exchange.SKIP_WWW_FORM_URLENCODED headers to the consumed exchange).

camel.sink.endpoint.disconnect.name: camel.sink.endpoint.disconnect
camel.sink.endpoint.disconnect.description: Whether or not to disconnect(close) from Netty Channel right after use. Can be used for both consumer and producer.

camel.sink.endpoint.keepAlive.name: camel.sink.endpoint.keepAlive
camel.sink.endpoint.keepAlive.description: Setting to ensure socket is not closed due to inactivity

camel.sink.endpoint.reuseChannel.name: camel.sink.endpoint.reuseChannel
camel.sink.endpoint.reuseChannel.description: This option allows producers and consumers (in client mode) to reuse the same Netty Channel for the lifecycle of processing the Exchange. This is useful if you need to call a server multiple times in a Camel route and want to use the same network connection. When using this, the channel is not returned to the connection pool until the Exchange is done; or disconnected if the disconnect option is set to true. The reused Channel is stored on the Exchange as an exchange property with the key NettyConstants#NETTY_CHANNEL which allows you to obtain the channel during routing and use it as well.

camel.sink.endpoint.sync.name: camel.sink.endpoint.sync
camel.sink.endpoint.sync.description: Setting to set endpoint as one-way or request-response

camel.sink.endpoint.tcpNoDelay.name: camel.sink.endpoint.tcpNoDelay
camel.sink.endpoint.tcpNoDelay.description: Setting to improve TCP protocol performance

camel.sink.endpoint.connectTimeout.name: camel.sink.endpoint.connectTimeout
camel.sink.endpoint.connectTimeout.description: Time to wait for a socket connection to be available. Value is in milliseconds.

camel.sink.endpoint.cookieHandler.name: camel.sink.endpoint.cookieHandler
camel.sink.endpoint.cookieHandler.description: Configure a cookie handler to maintain a HTTP session

camel.sink.endpoint.lazyStartProducer.name: camel.sink.endpoint.lazyStartProducer
camel.sink.endpoint.lazyStartProducer.description: Whether the producer should be started lazy (on the first message). By starting lazy you can use this to allow CamelContext and routes to startup in situations where a producer may otherwise fail during starting and cause the route to fail being started. By deferring this startup to be lazy then the startup failure can be handled during routing messages via Camel's routing error handlers. Beware that when the first message is processed then creating and starting the producer may take a little time and prolong the total processing time of the processing.

camel.sink.endpoint.requestTimeout.name: camel.sink.endpoint.requestTimeout
camel.sink.endpoint.requestTimeout.description: Allows to use a timeout for the Netty producer when calling a remote server. By default no timeout is in use. The value is in milli seconds, so eg 30000 is 30 seconds. The requestTimeout is using Netty's ReadTimeoutHandler to trigger the timeout.

camel.sink.endpoint.throwExceptionOnFail.name: camel.sink.endpoint.throwExceptionOnFailure
camel.sink.endpoint.throwExceptionOnFail.description: Option to disable throwing the HttpOperationFailedException in case of failed responses from the remote server. This allows you to get all responses regardless of the HTTP status code.

camel.sink.endpoint.lazyChannelCreation.name: camel.sink.endpoint.lazyChannelCreation
camel.sink.endpoint.lazyChannelCreation.description: Channels can be lazily created to avoid exceptions, if the remote server is not up and running when the Camel producer is started.

camel.sink.endpoint.okStatusCodeRange.name: camel.sink.endpoint.okStatusCodeRange
camel.sink.endpoint.okStatusCodeRange.description: The status codes which are considered a success response. The values are inclusive. Multiple ranges can be defined, separated by comma, e.g. 200-204,209,301-304. Each range must be a single number or from-to with the dash included. The default range is 200-299

camel.sink.endpoint.producerPoolEnabled.name: camel.sink.endpoint.producerPoolEnabled
camel.sink.endpoint.producerPoolEnabled.description: Whether producer pool is enabled or not. Important: If you turn this off then a single shared connection is used for the producer, also if you are doing request/reply. That means there is a potential issue with interleaved responses if replies comes back out-of-order. Therefore you need to have a correlation id in both the request and reply messages so you can properly correlate the replies to the Camel callback that is responsible for continue processing the message in Camel. To do this you need to implement NettyCamelStateCorrelationManager as correlation manager and configure it via the correlationManager option. See also the correlationManager option for more details.

camel.sink.endpoint.producerPoolMaxActiv.name: camel.sink.endpoint.producerPoolMaxActive
camel.sink.endpoint.producerPoolMaxActiv.description: Sets the cap on the number of objects that can be allocated by the pool (checked out to clients, or idle awaiting checkout) at a given time. Use a negative value for no limit.

camel.sink.endpoint.producerPoolMaxIdle.name: camel.sink.endpoint.producerPoolMaxIdle
camel.sink.endpoint.producerPoolMaxIdle.description: Sets the cap on the number of idle instances in the pool.

camel.sink.endpoint.producerPoolMinEvict.name: camel.sink.endpoint.producerPoolMinEvictableIdle
camel.sink.endpoint.producerPoolMinEvict.description: Sets the minimum amount of time (value in millis) an object may sit idle in the pool before it is eligible for eviction by the idle object evictor.

camel.sink.endpoint.producerPoolMinIdle.name: camel.sink.endpoint.producerPoolMinIdle
camel.sink.endpoint.producerPoolMinIdle.description: Sets the minimum number of instances allowed in the producer pool before the evictor thread (if active) spawns new objects.

camel.sink.endpoint.useRelativePath.name: camel.sink.endpoint.useRelativePath
camel.sink.endpoint.useRelativePath.description: Sets whether to use a relative path in HTTP requests.

camel.sink.endpoint.hostnameVerification.name: camel.sink.endpoint.hostnameVerification
camel.sink.endpoint.hostnameVerification.description: To enable/disable hostname verification on SSLEngine

camel.sink.endpoint.allowSerializedHeade.name: camel.sink.endpoint.allowSerializedHeaders
camel.sink.endpoint.allowSerializedHeade.description: Only used for TCP when transferExchange is true. When set to true, serializable objects in headers and properties will be added to the exchange. Otherwise Camel will exclude any non-serializable objects and log it at WARN level.

camel.sink.endpoint.configuration.name: camel.sink.endpoint.configuration
camel.sink.endpoint.configuration.description: To use a custom configured NettyHttpConfiguration for configuring this endpoint.

camel.sink.endpoint.disableStreamCache.name: camel.sink.endpoint.disableStreamCache
camel.sink.endpoint.disableStreamCache.description: Determines whether or not the raw input stream from Netty HttpRequest#getContent() or HttpResponset#getContent() is cached or not (Camel will read the stream into a in light-weight memory based Stream caching) cache. By default Camel will cache the Netty input stream to support reading it multiple times to ensure it Camel can retrieve all data from the stream. However you can set this option to true when you for example need to access the raw stream, such as streaming it directly to a file or other persistent store. Mind that if you enable this option, then you cannot read the Netty stream multiple times out of the box, and you would need manually to reset the reader index on the Netty raw stream. Also Netty will auto-close the Netty stream when the Netty HTTP server/HTTP client is done processing, which means that if the asynchronous routing engine is in use then any asynchronous thread that may continue routing the org.apache.camel.Exchange may not be able to read the Netty stream, because Netty has closed it.

camel.sink.endpoint.headerFilterStrategy.name: camel.sink.endpoint.headerFilterStrategy
camel.sink.endpoint.headerFilterStrategy.description: To use a custom org.apache.camel.spi.HeaderFilterStrategy to filter headers.

camel.sink.endpoint.nativeTransport.name: camel.sink.endpoint.nativeTransport
camel.sink.endpoint.nativeTransport.description: Whether to use native transport instead of NIO. Native transport takes advantage of the host operating system and is only supported on some platforms. You need to add the netty JAR for the host operating system you are using. See more details at: http://netty.io/wiki/native-transports.html

camel.sink.endpoint.nettyHttpBinding.name: camel.sink.endpoint.nettyHttpBinding
camel.sink.endpoint.nettyHttpBinding.description: To use a custom org.apache.camel.component.netty.http.NettyHttpBinding for binding to/from Netty and Camel Message API.

camel.sink.endpoint.options.name: camel.sink.endpoint.options
camel.sink.endpoint.options.description: Allows to configure additional netty options using option. as prefix. For example option.child.keepAlive=false to set the netty option child.keepAlive=false. See the Netty documentation for possible options that can be used.

camel.sink.endpoint.receiveBufferSize.name: camel.sink.endpoint.receiveBufferSize
camel.sink.endpoint.receiveBufferSize.description: The TCP/UDP buffer sizes to be used during inbound communication. Size is bytes.

camel.sink.endpoint.receiveBufferSizePre.name: camel.sink.endpoint.receiveBufferSizePredictor
camel.sink.endpoint.receiveBufferSizePre.description: Configures the buffer size predictor. See details at Jetty documentation and this mail thread.

camel.sink.endpoint.sendBufferSize.name: camel.sink.endpoint.sendBufferSize
camel.sink.endpoint.sendBufferSize.description: The TCP/UDP buffer sizes to be used during outbound communication. Size is bytes.

camel.sink.endpoint.synchronous.name: camel.sink.endpoint.synchronous
camel.sink.endpoint.synchronous.description: Sets whether synchronous processing should be strictly used

camel.sink.endpoint.transferException.name: camel.sink.endpoint.transferException
camel.sink.endpoint.transferException.description: If enabled and an Exchange failed processing on the consumer side, and if the caused Exception was send back serialized in the response as a application/x-java-serialized-object content type. On the producer side the exception will be deserialized and thrown as is, instead of the HttpOperationFailedException. The caused exception is required to be serialized. This is by default turned off. If you enable this then be aware that Java will deserialize the incoming data from the request to Java and that can be a potential security risk.

camel.sink.endpoint.transferExchange.name: camel.sink.endpoint.transferExchange
camel.sink.endpoint.transferExchange.description: Only used for TCP. You can transfer the exchange over the wire instead of just the body. The following fields are transferred: In body, Out body, fault body, In headers, Out headers, fault headers, exchange properties, exchange exception. This requires that the objects are serializable. Camel will exclude any non-serializable objects and log it at WARN level.

camel.sink.endpoint.workerCount.name: camel.sink.endpoint.workerCount
camel.sink.endpoint.workerCount.description: When netty works on nio mode, it uses default workerCount parameter from Netty (which is cpu_core_threads x 2). User can use this option to override the default workerCount from Netty.

camel.sink.endpoint.workerGroup.name: camel.sink.endpoint.workerGroup
camel.sink.endpoint.workerGroup.description: To use a explicit EventLoopGroup as the boss thread pool. For example to share a thread pool with multiple consumers or producers. By default each consumer or producer has their own worker pool with 2 x cpu count core threads.

camel.sink.endpoint.decoders.name: camel.sink.endpoint.decoders
camel.sink.endpoint.decoders.description: A list of decoders to be used. You can use a String which have values separated by comma, and have the values be looked up in the Registry. Just remember to prefix the value with # so Camel knows it should lookup.

camel.sink.endpoint.encoders.name: camel.sink.endpoint.encoders
camel.sink.endpoint.encoders.description: A list of encoders to be used. You can use a String which have values separated by comma, and have the values be looked up in the Registry. Just remember to prefix the value with # so Camel knows it should lookup.

camel.sink.endpoint.enabledProtocols.name: camel.sink.endpoint.enabledProtocols
camel.sink.endpoint.enabledProtocols.description: Which protocols to enable when using SSL

camel.sink.endpoint.keyStoreFile.name: camel.sink.endpoint.keyStoreFile
camel.sink.endpoint.keyStoreFile.description: Client side certificate keystore to be used for encryption

camel.sink.endpoint.keyStoreFormat.name: camel.sink.endpoint.keyStoreFormat
camel.sink.endpoint.keyStoreFormat.description: Keystore format to be used for payload encryption. Defaults to JKS if not set

camel.sink.endpoint.keyStoreResource.name: camel.sink.endpoint.keyStoreResource
camel.sink.endpoint.keyStoreResource.description: Client side certificate keystore to be used for encryption. Is loaded by default from classpath, but you can prefix with classpath:, file:, or http: to load the resource from different systems.

camel.sink.endpoint.passphrase.name: camel.sink.endpoint.passphrase
camel.sink.endpoint.passphrase.description: Password setting to use in order to encrypt/decrypt payloads sent using SSH

camel.sink.endpoint.securityProvider.name: camel.sink.endpoint.securityProvider
camel.sink.endpoint.securityProvider.description: Security provider to be used for payload encryption. Defaults to SunX509 if not set.

camel.sink.endpoint.ssl.name: camel.sink.endpoint.ssl
camel.sink.endpoint.ssl.description: Setting to specify whether SSL encryption is applied to this endpoint

camel.sink.endpoint.sslClientCertHeaders.name: camel.sink.endpoint.sslClientCertHeaders
camel.sink.endpoint.sslClientCertHeaders.description: When enabled and in SSL mode, then the Netty consumer will enrich the Camel Message with headers having information about the client certificate such as subject name, issuer name, serial number, and the valid date range.

camel.sink.endpoint.sslHandler.name: camel.sink.endpoint.sslHandler
camel.sink.endpoint.sslHandler.description: Reference to a class that could be used to return an SSL Handler

camel.sink.endpoint.trustStoreFile.name: camel.sink.endpoint.trustStoreFile
camel.sink.endpoint.trustStoreFile.description: Server side certificate keystore to be used for encryption

camel.sink.endpoint.trustStoreResource.name: camel.sink.endpoint.trustStoreResource
camel.sink.endpoint.trustStoreResource.description: Server side certificate keystore to be used for encryption. Is loaded by default from classpath, but you can prefix with classpath:, file:, or http: to load the resource from different systems.

camel.component.netty-http.configuration.name: camel.component.netty-http.configuration
camel.component.netty-http.configuration.description: To use the NettyConfiguration as configuration when creating endpoints.

camel.component.netty-http.disconnect.name: camel.component.netty-http.disconnect
camel.component.netty-http.disconnect.description: Whether or not to disconnect(close) from Netty Channel right after use. Can be used for both consumer and producer.

camel.component.netty-http.keepAlive.name: camel.component.netty-http.keepAlive
camel.component.netty-http.keepAlive.description: Setting to ensure socket is not closed due to inactivity

camel.component.netty-http.reuseChannel.name: camel.component.netty-http.reuseChannel
camel.component.netty-http.reuseChannel.description: This option allows producers and consumers (in client mode) to reuse the same Netty Channel for the lifecycle of processing the Exchange. This is useful if you need to call a server multiple times in a Camel route and want to use the same network connection. When using this, the channel is not returned to the connection pool until the Exchange is done; or disconnected if the disconnect option is set to true. The reused Channel is stored on the Exchange as an exchange property with the key NettyConstants#NETTY_CHANNEL which allows you to obtain the channel during routing and use it as well.

camel.component.netty-http.sync.name: camel.component.netty-http.sync
camel.component.netty-http.sync.description: Setting to set endpoint as one-way or request-response

camel.component.netty-http.tcpNoDelay.name: camel.component.netty-http.tcpNoDelay
camel.component.netty-http.tcpNoDelay.description: Setting to improve TCP protocol performance

camel.component.netty-http.connectTimeou.name: camel.component.netty-http.connectTimeout
camel.component.netty-http.connectTimeou.description: Time to wait for a socket connection to be available. Value is in milliseconds.

camel.component.netty-http.lazyStartProd.name: camel.component.netty-http.lazyStartProducer
camel.component.netty-http.lazyStartProd.description: Whether the producer should be started lazy (on the first message). By starting lazy you can use this to allow CamelContext and routes to startup in situations where a producer may otherwise fail during starting and cause the route to fail being started. By deferring this startup to be lazy then the startup failure can be handled during routing messages via Camel's routing error handlers. Beware that when the first message is processed then creating and starting the producer may take a little time and prolong the total processing time of the processing.

camel.component.netty-http.requestTimeou.name: camel.component.netty-http.requestTimeout
camel.component.netty-http.requestTimeou.description: Allows to use a timeout for the Netty producer when calling a remote server. By default no timeout is in use. The value is in milli seconds, so eg 30000 is 30 seconds. The requestTimeout is using Netty's ReadTimeoutHandler to trigger the timeout.

camel.component.netty-http.correlationMa.name: camel.component.netty-http.correlationManager
camel.component.netty-http.correlationMa.description: To use a custom correlation manager to manage how request and reply messages are mapped when using request/reply with the netty producer. This should only be used if you have a way to map requests together with replies such as if there is correlation ids in both the request and reply messages. This can be used if you want to multiplex concurrent messages on the same channel (aka connection) in netty. When doing this you must have a way to correlate the request and reply messages so you can store the right reply on the inflight Camel Exchange before its continued routed. We recommend extending the TimeoutCorrelationManagerSupport when you build custom correlation managers. This provides support for timeout and other complexities you otherwise would need to implement as well. See also the producerPoolEnabled option for more details.

camel.component.netty-http.lazyChannelCr.name: camel.component.netty-http.lazyChannelCreation
camel.component.netty-http.lazyChannelCr.description: Channels can be lazily created to avoid exceptions, if the remote server is not up and running when the Camel producer is started.

camel.component.netty-http.producerPoolE.name: camel.component.netty-http.producerPoolEnabled
camel.component.netty-http.producerPoolE.description: Whether producer pool is enabled or not. Important: If you turn this off then a single shared connection is used for the producer, also if you are doing request/reply. That means there is a potential issue with interleaved responses if replies comes back out-of-order. Therefore you need to have a correlation id in both the request and reply messages so you can properly correlate the replies to the Camel callback that is responsible for continue processing the message in Camel. To do this you need to implement NettyCamelStateCorrelationManager as correlation manager and configure it via the correlationManager option. See also the correlationManager option for more details.

camel.component.netty-http.producerPoolM.name: camel.component.netty-http.producerPoolMaxActive
camel.component.netty-http.producerPoolM.description: Sets the cap on the number of objects that can be allocated by the pool (checked out to clients, or idle awaiting checkout) at a given time. Use a negative value for no limit.

camel.component.netty-http.producerPoolM.name: camel.component.netty-http.producerPoolMaxIdle
camel.component.netty-http.producerPoolM.description: Sets the cap on the number of idle instances in the pool.

camel.component.netty-http.producerPoolM.name: camel.component.netty-http.producerPoolMinEvictableIdle
camel.component.netty-http.producerPoolM.description: Sets the minimum amount of time (value in millis) an object may sit idle in the pool before it is eligible for eviction by the idle object evictor.

camel.component.netty-http.producerPoolM.name: camel.component.netty-http.producerPoolMinIdle
camel.component.netty-http.producerPoolM.description: Sets the minimum number of instances allowed in the producer pool before the evictor thread (if active) spawns new objects.

camel.component.netty-http.udpConnection.name: camel.component.netty-http.udpConnectionlessSending
camel.component.netty-http.udpConnection.description: This option supports connection less udp sending which is a real fire and forget. A connected udp send receive the PortUnreachableException if no one is listen on the receiving port.

camel.component.netty-http.useByteBuf.name: camel.component.netty-http.useByteBuf
camel.component.netty-http.useByteBuf.description: If the useByteBuf is true, netty producer will turn the message body into ByteBuf before sending it out.

camel.component.netty-http.hostnameVerif.name: camel.component.netty-http.hostnameVerification
camel.component.netty-http.hostnameVerif.description: To enable/disable hostname verification on SSLEngine

camel.component.netty-http.allowSerializ.name: camel.component.netty-http.allowSerializedHeaders
camel.component.netty-http.allowSerializ.description: Only used for TCP when transferExchange is true. When set to true, serializable objects in headers and properties will be added to the exchange. Otherwise Camel will exclude any non-serializable objects and log it at WARN level.

camel.component.netty-http.autowiredEnab.name: camel.component.netty-http.autowiredEnabled
camel.component.netty-http.autowiredEnab.description: Whether autowiring is enabled. This is used for automatic autowiring options (the option must be marked as autowired) by looking up in the registry to find if there is a single instance of matching type, which then gets configured on the component. This can be used for automatic configuring JDBC data sources, JMS connection factories, AWS Clients, etc.

camel.component.netty-http.headerFilterS.name: camel.component.netty-http.headerFilterStrategy
camel.component.netty-http.headerFilterS.description: To use a custom org.apache.camel.spi.HeaderFilterStrategy to filter headers.

camel.component.netty-http.nativeTranspo.name: camel.component.netty-http.nativeTransport
camel.component.netty-http.nativeTranspo.description: Whether to use native transport instead of NIO. Native transport takes advantage of the host operating system and is only supported on some platforms. You need to add the netty JAR for the host operating system you are using. See more details at: http://netty.io/wiki/native-transports.html

camel.component.netty-http.nettyHttpBind.name: camel.component.netty-http.nettyHttpBinding
camel.component.netty-http.nettyHttpBind.description: To use a custom org.apache.camel.component.netty.http.NettyHttpBinding for binding to/from Netty and Camel Message API.

camel.component.netty-http.options.name: camel.component.netty-http.options
camel.component.netty-http.options.description: Allows to configure additional netty options using option. as prefix. For example option.child.keepAlive=false to set the netty option child.keepAlive=false. See the Netty documentation for possible options that can be used.

camel.component.netty-http.receiveBuffer.name: camel.component.netty-http.receiveBufferSize
camel.component.netty-http.receiveBuffer.description: The TCP/UDP buffer sizes to be used during inbound communication. Size is bytes.

camel.component.netty-http.receiveBuffer.name: camel.component.netty-http.receiveBufferSizePredictor
camel.component.netty-http.receiveBuffer.description: Configures the buffer size predictor. See details at Jetty documentation and this mail thread.

camel.component.netty-http.sendBufferSiz.name: camel.component.netty-http.sendBufferSize
camel.component.netty-http.sendBufferSiz.description: The TCP/UDP buffer sizes to be used during outbound communication. Size is bytes.

camel.component.netty-http.transferExcha.name: camel.component.netty-http.transferExchange
camel.component.netty-http.transferExcha.description: Only used for TCP. You can transfer the exchange over the wire instead of just the body. The following fields are transferred: In body, Out body, fault body, In headers, Out headers, fault headers, exchange properties, exchange exception. This requires that the objects are serializable. Camel will exclude any non-serializable objects and log it at WARN level.

camel.component.netty-http.udpByteArrayC.name: camel.component.netty-http.udpByteArrayCodec
camel.component.netty-http.udpByteArrayC.description: For UDP only. If enabled the using byte array codec instead of Java serialization protocol.

camel.component.netty-http.workerCount.name: camel.component.netty-http.workerCount
camel.component.netty-http.workerCount.description: When netty works on nio mode, it uses default workerCount parameter from Netty (which is cpu_core_threads x 2). User can use this option to override the default workerCount from Netty.

camel.component.netty-http.workerGroup.name: camel.component.netty-http.workerGroup
camel.component.netty-http.workerGroup.description: To use a explicit EventLoopGroup as the boss thread pool. For example to share a thread pool with multiple consumers or producers. By default each consumer or producer has their own worker pool with 2 x cpu count core threads.

camel.component.netty-http.allowDefaultC.name: camel.component.netty-http.allowDefaultCodec
camel.component.netty-http.allowDefaultC.description: The netty component installs a default codec if both, encoder/decoder is null and textline is false. Setting allowDefaultCodec to false prevents the netty component from installing a default codec as the first element in the filter chain.

camel.component.netty-http.autoAppendDel.name: camel.component.netty-http.autoAppendDelimiter
camel.component.netty-http.autoAppendDel.description: Whether or not to auto append missing end delimiter when sending using the textline codec.

camel.component.netty-http.decoderMaxLin.name: camel.component.netty-http.decoderMaxLineLength
camel.component.netty-http.decoderMaxLin.description: The max line length to use for the textline codec.

camel.component.netty-http.decoders.name: camel.component.netty-http.decoders
camel.component.netty-http.decoders.description: A list of decoders to be used. You can use a String which have values separated by comma, and have the values be looked up in the Registry. Just remember to prefix the value with # so Camel knows it should lookup.

camel.component.netty-http.delimiter.name: camel.component.netty-http.delimiter
camel.component.netty-http.delimiter.description: The delimiter to use for the textline codec. Possible values are LINE and NULL. One of: [LINE] [NULL]

camel.component.netty-http.encoders.name: camel.component.netty-http.encoders
camel.component.netty-http.encoders.description: A list of encoders to be used. You can use a String which have values separated by comma, and have the values be looked up in the Registry. Just remember to prefix the value with # so Camel knows it should lookup.

camel.component.netty-http.encoding.name: camel.component.netty-http.encoding
camel.component.netty-http.encoding.description: The encoding (a charset name) to use for the textline codec. If not provided, Camel will use the JVM default Charset.

camel.component.netty-http.textline.name: camel.component.netty-http.textline
camel.component.netty-http.textline.description: Only used for TCP. If no codec is specified, you can use this flag to indicate a text line based codec; if not specified or the value is false, then Object Serialization is assumed over TCP - however only Strings are allowed to be serialized by default.

camel.component.netty-http.enabledProtoc.name: camel.component.netty-http.enabledProtocols
camel.component.netty-http.enabledProtoc.description: Which protocols to enable when using SSL

camel.component.netty-http.keyStoreFile.name: camel.component.netty-http.keyStoreFile
camel.component.netty-http.keyStoreFile.description: Client side certificate keystore to be used for encryption

camel.component.netty-http.keyStoreForma.name: camel.component.netty-http.keyStoreFormat
camel.component.netty-http.keyStoreForma.description: Keystore format to be used for payload encryption. Defaults to JKS if not set

camel.component.netty-http.keyStoreResou.name: camel.component.netty-http.keyStoreResource
camel.component.netty-http.keyStoreResou.description: Client side certificate keystore to be used for encryption. Is loaded by default from classpath, but you can prefix with classpath:, file:, or http: to load the resource from different systems.

camel.component.netty-http.passphrase.name: camel.component.netty-http.passphrase
camel.component.netty-http.passphrase.description: Password setting to use in order to encrypt/decrypt payloads sent using SSH

camel.component.netty-http.securityConfi.name: camel.component.netty-http.securityConfiguration
camel.component.netty-http.securityConfi.description: Refers to a org.apache.camel.component.netty.http.NettyHttpSecurityConfiguration for configuring secure web resources.

camel.component.netty-http.securityProvi.name: camel.component.netty-http.securityProvider
camel.component.netty-http.securityProvi.description: Security provider to be used for payload encryption. Defaults to SunX509 if not set.

camel.component.netty-http.ssl.name: camel.component.netty-http.ssl
camel.component.netty-http.ssl.description: Setting to specify whether SSL encryption is applied to this endpoint

camel.component.netty-http.sslClientCert.name: camel.component.netty-http.sslClientCertHeaders
camel.component.netty-http.sslClientCert.description: When enabled and in SSL mode, then the Netty consumer will enrich the Camel Message with headers having information about the client certificate such as subject name, issuer name, serial number, and the valid date range.

camel.component.netty-http.sslHandler.name: camel.component.netty-http.sslHandler
camel.component.netty-http.sslHandler.description: Reference to a class that could be used to return an SSL Handler

camel.component.netty-http.trustStoreFil.name: camel.component.netty-http.trustStoreFile
camel.component.netty-http.trustStoreFil.description: Server side certificate keystore to be used for encryption

camel.component.netty-http.trustStoreRes.name: camel.component.netty-http.trustStoreResource
camel.component.netty-http.trustStoreRes.description: Server side certificate keystore to be used for encryption. Is loaded by default from classpath, but you can prefix with classpath:, file:, or http: to load the resource from different systems.

camel.component.netty-http.useGlobalSslC.name: camel.component.netty-http.useGlobalSslContextParameters
camel.component.netty-http.useGlobalSslC.description: Enable usage of global SSL context parameters.
